message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious projectile vomiting, distended upper abdomen, and localized gas collections in the upper abdomen suggest a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. Duodenal atresia would show double bubble sign on x-ray, meconium ileus would show intestinal obstruction, and Hirschsprung disease would show rectal biopsy with absence of ganglion cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious projectile vomiting, distended upper abdomen, and localized gas collections in the upper abdomen are suggestive of jejunal atresia. Meconium ileus often presents with failure to pass meconium, Hirschsprung disease with failure to pass stool, and duodenal atresia with double-bubble sign on x-ray. Polyhydramnios and maternal smoking are associated with jejunal atresia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's symptoms and physical examination suggest a bowel obstruction. The presence of bilious projectile vomiting and 3 distinct, localized gas collections in the upper abdomen point towards jejunal atresia as the most likely diagnosis. Polyhydramnios and maternal cigarette smoking are also risk factors for this condition. Duodenal atresia would present with double-bubble sign on x-ray, meconium ileus would cause distal intestinal obstruction, and Hirschsprung disease would cause constipation and delayed passage of meconium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's symptoms suggest a bowel obstruction. The fact that there are localized gas collections in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen is most suggestive of jejunal atresia. Duodenal atresia presents with a "double-bubble" sign on x-ray, Meconium ileus presents with the absence of gas in the rectum, and Hirschsprung disease presents with a dilated colon on x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious projectile vomiting and distended upper abdomen suggest obstruction in the upper gastrointestinal tract. The fact that there are multiple gas collections in the upper abdomen makes duodenal atresia less likely and the absence of gas in the distal abdomen excludes Hirschsprung disease. Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis, which is not mentioned in the question stem. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is jejunal atresia, which is associated with polyhydramnios and smoking during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bilious projectile vomiting, distended upper abdomen, and localized gas collections in the upper abdomen on an x-ray all suggest Jejunal atresia. Duodenal atresia and Meconium ileus would show a gasless abdomen, while Hirschsprung disease would present as failure to pass meconium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms suggest a bowel obstruction, and the x-ray shows localized gas collections in the upper abdomen, indicating the obstruction site. Among the options, Jejunal atresia is most likely as it occurs in about 1 in 5000 live births and has polyhydramnios as one of the risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest a diagnosis of jejunal atresia, which is characterized by bilious vomiting, distended upper abdomen and gas-filled loops in the upper abdomen on imaging. Duodenal atresia and Meconium ileus also cause bilious vomiting but Duodenal atresia is associated with "double bubble" sign on x-ray and Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis. Hirschsprung disease is associated with failure to pass meconium and distended abdomen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intestinal obstruction, and the x-ray shows 3 distinct gas collections in the upper abdomen, which is characteristic of jejunal atresia. Polyhydramnios increases the risk of intestinal obstruction in newborns. Duodenal atresia presents with “double-bubble” sign on x-ray, Meconium ileus presents with generalized distention, and Hirschsprung disease presents with delayed passage of meconium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The distended upper abdomen and localized gas collections in the upper abdomen suggest a small bowel obstruction. Among the options, jejunal atresia is most likely as it is often associated with polyhydramnios and has a higher incidence in infants of mothers who smoked during pregnancy. Duodenal atresia usually presents with double bubble sign on x-ray, meconium ileus with distended loop of bowel and multiple dilated bowel loops, and Hirschsprung disease with constipation and failure to pass meconium in the first 48 hours.
